translated: Bodhisattva-caryavatara, Chapter 6
By the Arya Nagarjuna, explained by the Bhiksu Jina
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Dharmagupta of the Great Sui Dynasty from South India
Question:
How does one cultivate?
Answer:
The four bases of supernatural power are the roots, namely desire, effort, thought, and investigation;
The four immeasurables are the supports, namely kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity.
Having cultivated and practiced the four immeasurables extensively, one attains mental capability.
Having attained mental capability, one then enters the first dhyana, the second, the third, and the fourth in the same way.

Having attained these dhyanas, one attains lightness of body and mind. Because one is endowed with lightness of body and mind, one gives rise to the supernormal powers of spiritual penetrations. Because one is endowed with the supernormal powers of spiritual penetrations, one gives rise to the bases of spiritual power, namely desire, effort, mind, and investigation.
Among them, desire is the inclination towards the Dharma, effort is the accomplishment of the Dharma, mind is the contemplation of the Dharma, and contemplation is skillfulness in the Dharma.

Regarding the supernormal powers, if the bodhisattva has faith and understanding, or if he engages in activities, his mind is free and he acts as he wishes. Because he has perfected [the supernormal powers], and because he abides in his own fundamental support, he moves through all realms as easily as the wind moves through space.

Among them, the bodhisattva, having attained the four immeasurables and the four dhyÄnas, if he has faith and understanding, or if he engages in activities, gives rise to the divine eye. Whether it be the divine eye of the devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, etc., or the divine eye of the learners, Å›rÄvakas, and pratyekabuddhas, among them he alone has the superior power, surpassing them in purity, surpassing them in radiance, surpassing them in leadership, and surpassing them in uniqueness. His eye is unobstructed, and he can see all the coarse and subtle, distant and near, forms in the world, just as he wishes.

In this way, one hears the sounds of gods, humans, animals, and so forth. In this way, one recollects and knows the boundless and limitless past. In this way, one knows the minds of others, together with greed and so forth, up to the eighty-four thousand distinctions. In this way, one attains immeasurable spiritual powers.
Because of attaining spiritual powers, all sentient beings who should be subdued are made to be subdued.
The four elements are like poisonous snakes, the six sense bases are like an empty village,
The five aggregates are like murderers, one should contemplate in this way.

For a long time, although one has used various enjoyable things as causes for enjoyment, protected, nurtured, and developed these four elements such as earth and so forth, they quickly become agitated. Because they do not know gratitude, cannot be relied upon, and cannot be trusted, one should contemplate them as being like poisonous snakes, because they have no master and are devoid of I and mine.

The six sense bases such as the eye are like a group of six thieves, because they are oppressive and terrifying. One should contemplate them as if they were an empty village, because they cannot be blocked or obstructed by giving them things and making peace with them, as if they were killers.
One should contemplate the five aggregates of clinging in this way every day.
One should also abandon stinginess with the Dharma,
and the teacher should not hold back the Dharma, and the listener should not be distracted.
There are four kinds of dharmas that can give rise to great wisdom, which one should accept and uphold.
One should revere the Dharma and the Dharma teacher;
one should also abandon stinginess with the Dharma, and teach others what one has heard and memorized;
if there are those who delight in the Dharma, the teacher should not hold back;
and the listener should not be distracted, meaning one should not have other desires.
Without arrogance or expectation, with a mind of compassion alone,
with a respectful and reverent attitude, one should expound the Dharma for the assembly.
There are also four kinds of dharmas that are the characteristics of great wisdom, which should be accepted and taken up.
Namely, being free from self-conceit and despising others, because of being without arrogance.
Abandoning gain, offerings, respect, and fame, because of having no mind of expectation.
Among sentient beings who are obscured by the darkness of ignorance, only out of compassion and pity, one should respect and revere them and expound the Dharma for them.
Because of these four kinds of dharmas, the great wisdom of the bodhisattva is complete, and one should accept and take them up.
Not being content with hearing, having heard, all reciting and upholding,
Not deceiving the honored field of merit, and also causing the teacher to rejoice.

Having heard much, being insatiable, having heard, upholding the Dharma, having upheld the Dharma, practicing the Dharma in accordance with the Dharma, not deceiving the honored field of merit, and also causing the teacher to rejoice - this Dharma.
Is the cause of not forgetting the mind of enlightenment.
One should not observe other families, with a mind full of respect and support,
One should not study and recite worldly texts for the sake of debate and difficulty.
One should not go to other people's homes to seek offerings and respect, except for the sake of establishing the cause of the bodhi mind.
One should also not study and recite various worldly treatises for the sake of debate, except for the sake of extensive learning.ğŸ”½Do not out of anger,
Slander the bodhisattvas,
And do not slander the Dharma that has not been received or heard.
Why is it so?
In order to protect the causes and conditions for the continuation of wholesome dharmas.
Cut off arrogance and abide in the four noble lineages,
Do not despise others, and do not be self-important.
As for cutting off arrogance, one should lower one's mind like a dog towards all sentient beings, and cut off self-conceit.
One should also abide in the four noble lineages of meager clothing, food, bedding, and medicine, because one is content with those noble lineages.
One should not despise others, nor should one be self-important.
If it is true or not, one should not expose the faults of others,
And should not seek out the mistakes of others, but should be aware of one's own mistakes.
If one's fellow practitioners of pure conduct have committed offenses, whether true or not, one should not expose them.
One should not seek out the mistakes of others, but should be aware of one's own mistakes.
The Buddha and the teachings of the Buddhas should not be doubted or discriminated,
Although the teachings are the most difficult to believe, one should have faith in them.
One should not discriminate with regard to the Buddha, because the World-Honored One is endowed with unprecedented qualities.
One should also not doubt the teachings of the Buddha, because they are the uncommon qualities of all sentient beings.
And within the most difficult to believe teachings of the Buddha, one should have faith with a pure and profound mind.
Even if one dies due to speaking the truth, and loses the status of a wheel-turning king,
And even the status of a heavenly king, one should still only speak the truth.

If a bodhisattva, due to speaking the truth, were to lose his possessions or die, even if he were to lose the status of a wheel-turning king or the status of various heavenly kings, he should still speak the truth. How much more so for other matters, he should not speak falsely.
Beating, scolding, frightening, killing, and binding, one should never resent others,
All of these are my own sins, manifesting due to the retribution of karma.
If others come to beat, scold, frighten, kill, bind, or imprison one, all of these are due to one's own sins. One should not be angry with others.
This is my karma, which I created in previous lives. Now I am experiencing the similar unpleasant fruits.
Those sentient beings are completely without fault. It is only my own sinful karmic retribution that manifests. This should be so.ğŸ”½One should greatly respect and love one's parents,
and also serve one's preceptor, and respectfully regard one's teacher.
Toward one's parents, one should have utmost love, respect, and offerings, and should think of them as deities. One should bring them joy by following their wishes, free from flattery and deception.

Moreover, one should respectfully serve and attend to one's preceptor and master, and in the Dharma taught by the preceptor and master, one should have no secrets, but rather should outwardly transform [others].
For those who have faith in the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle and the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle,
to expound the most profound Dharma is a mistake for a bodhisattva.
Herein, there are four kinds of mistakes made by bodhisattvas that should be abandoned.
Namely, for those beings in the ÅšrÄvaka and Pratyekabuddha Vehicles, to expound the most profound Dharma is a mistake for a bodhisattva.
For beings who have faith in the profound MahÄyÄna, to expound
the ÅšrÄvaka and Pratyekabuddha Vehicles is also a mistake.
For those beings who have faith in the profound MahÄyÄna, to expound the ÅšrÄvaka and Pratyekabuddha Vehicles is a mistake for a bodhisattva.
When great beings come seeking the Dharma, if one is slow and does not teach,
And instead accepts evil, entrusting the faithless,

If there are those who abide in the great assembly and come seeking something, one should immediately teach them the good Dharma, yet one is more slow and lax, breaking the precepts and being evil in Dharma.
To accept this is a mistake for a bodhisattva.

Those who have not yet attained faith and understanding in the Great Vehicle, and those who have not yet matured through the four means of gathering disciples, to trust them is a mistake for a bodhisattva.
These are the four kinds.
The mistakes that are spoken of should be abandoned from afar, the virtues of the sutras should be spoken of,
Regarding them one should know and remember, and also should cultivate and be close to them.
The four kinds of mistakes spoken of here should be abandoned from afar, because they distance one from enlightenment.
If the virtues of the sutras and others spoken of in the Hearers' and Solitary Buddhas' Vehicles do not create obstacles to enlightenment, one should cultivate and be close to them.
With an equal mind, speaking equally, well-established equally,
Also causing proper correspondence, all sentient beings are no different.
These four kinds of bodhisattva paths should be cultivated and practiced.
What are the four?

Namely, giving rise to an equal mind towards all sentient beings, speaking the Dharma equally to all sentient beings, well-establishing all sentient beings equally, and causing all sentient beings to be properly corresponding.
These are all without distinction, and are the four kinds.
Not for profit but for the Dharma, not for fame but for virtue,
Desiring to liberate sentient beings from suffering, not desiring one's own happiness.
These four kinds of true bodhisattvas should be aware of.
What are the four?
Namely, only for the Dharma, not for material gain; only for merit, not for fame; only desiring to liberate sentient beings from suffering; not desiring one's own peace and happiness.
Seeking the results of karma with a hidden intention, the meritorious deeds one performs arise,
And in order to mature sentient beings, one abandons one's own affairs.

If one wishes to seek the results of karma with a hidden intention and perform the three meritorious deeds, when these merits arise, it is only for the benefit and happiness of sentient beings, and it is only for the benefit of sentient beings that one matures sentient beings and abandons one's own affairs for the sake of benefiting sentient beings.
These are the four kinds of true bodhisattvas.
One should draw near to good and virtuous friends, namely Dharma teachers and Buddhas,
And encourage those who have left the household life, as well as those who beg for alms.
These four kinds of bodhisattvas are good and virtuous friends whom one should draw near to.
What are the four?
Namely, Dharma teachers are good and virtuous friends for bodhisattvas, because they assist in upholding the wisdom of hearing.
The World-Honored Buddha is a good and virtuous friend for bodhisattvas, because he assists in upholding the teachings of the Buddhas.
Those who encourage leaving the household life are good and virtuous friends for bodhisattvas, because they assist in upholding all wholesome roots.
Beggars are the good and virtuous friends of bodhisattvas, because they assist in upholding the bodhi mind.
These four kinds of good and virtuous friends of bodhisattvas should be closely associated with.
Those who rely on worldly treatises, those who exclusively seek worldly wealth,
Those who have faith in the pratyekabuddha vehicle and the Å›rÄvaka vehicle.
These four kinds of bad and virtuous friends of bodhisattvas should be known.
What are the four?
Namely, those who rely on worldly treatises, because they are accustomed to various kinds of mixed eloquence.
Those who hoard worldly wealth and goods, because they do not hoard the Dharma.
Those of the pratyekabuddha vehicle, because they have little benefit and do few things.
Those of the Å›rÄvaka vehicle, because they practice for their own benefit.
These four kinds of bad and virtuous friends, bodhisattvas should know,
And there are those who should be sought, namely the four great treasures.
As previously explained, the four kinds of virtuous friends are bad and virtuous friends. Knowing this, one should avoid them.
There are also those who should attain through seeking, namely the four great treasuries.
Hearing the perfections when the Buddha appears, and from the Dharma teachers,
Seeing with an unobstructed mind, delighting in dwelling in secluded places.
These four kinds of great treasuries of bodhisattvas should be attained.
What are the four?

Namely, serving the Buddhas who appear in the world, listening to the six perfections, seeing the Dharma teachers with an unobstructed mind, and delighting in dwelling in secluded places without negligence.
These are the four kinds of great treasuries of bodhisattvas that should be attained.
Earth, water, fire, wind, and space, all similar to it,
Equal in all places, benefiting all sentient beings.
Similar to the earth, water, fire, wind, and space, there are two causes and conditions that bodhisattvas should embrace, namely equality and benefit.
Just as the five great elements such as earth and space are equal in all places, with and without mind, without any different characteristics.
Beings always rely on them without changing or seeking repayment.
I am also like this, up to the ultimate stage of enlightenment, being relied upon by all beings without changing or seeking repayment.
You should contemplate the meaning well and diligently give rise to dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s,
Do not create obstacles for those who listen to the Dharma.
As for the meaning, the meaning spoken by the Buddha, you should contemplate it well, whether discussing it with others or staying alone, you should act in this way.
Moreover, abide in the precepts with a pure mind, diligently give rise to purity, and hear the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s such as the silver lord, ocean lord, and so forth.
Moreover, do not create obstacles for those who listen to the Dharma due to trivial reasons, in order to avoid the karma that gives rise to calamities to the Dharma.
In the midst of vexation, one is able to subdue, and for minor matters, one relinquishes without remainder,
The eight kinds of lazy matters, all should also be eliminated and severed.

In the midst of vexation, one is able to subdue - within this, there are nine kinds of vexing matters, namely, that which brings no benefit to me, has done, is doing, or will do, these are the three kinds.
That which brings no benefit to my loved ones, has done, is doing, or will do, again forms three kinds.
That which brings benefit to those I dislike and despise,
has done, is doing, or will do, again forms three kinds.
These are all vexing matters.
Within these nine kinds of vexing matters, one should subdue oneself.

As for abandoning the remaining minor matters, there are twenty kinds of minor matters, namely: lack of faith, shamelessness, flattery and deception, agitation, distraction, negligence, harmfulness, lack of conscience, laziness, worry, dullness, sleep, sleep, resentment, concealment, jealousy, stinginess, arrogance, anger, regret, and depression.
These twenty kinds of minor matters are all abandoned without remainder.

The eight kinds of lazy activities should also be eliminated. There are eight kinds of lazy activities, namely: I want to do work and then lie down comfortably without making effort, I have done work, I am on the road, I have traveled on the road, my body is tired and unable to cultivate, my body is heavy and unable to cultivate, I have already become ill, I have recovered from illness and lie down comfortably without making effort.
Because of these, one should attain but does not attain, should reach but does not reach, should realize but does not realize.
In order to eliminate these eight kinds of lazy activities, one should arouse diligence.
Do not be greedy for what is not one's share, do not be greedy for what does not accord with one's wishes,
Separate those who are separated, regardless of whether they are close or not.
If one sees sentient beings who are endowed with abundant offerings, fame, comfort, praise, and blessings, do not be greedy for their abundant blessings.
Because making improper greedy thoughts does not accord with the mind, therefore it is not something that should be done.
Moreover, among those beings who are separated and destroyed by various disputes, whether they are close or not, all are brought together in harmony and love each other with the same mind.
Those who attain emptiness through emptiness, the wise should not rely on practice,
If one attains emptiness, then the evil view of the body is surpassed.
Therefore, the wise should not rely on attaining emptiness through emptiness and practice, because by relying on emptiness one uproots the great mass of ignorance.
If one relies on attaining emptiness and practices, then the evil that is more difficult to treat than the view of the existence of a body is surpassed.

Because the practice of views is liberated through emptiness, if one is attached to the view of emptiness, they are incurable, because there is no further liberation.ğŸ”½Sweeping, anointing, and adorning, as well as various kinds of drumming and music,
Incense, garlands, and other offering implements, offering to the caitya.

In the presence of the TathÄgata's relics and images, one should make offerings by sweeping the ground, anointing the ground, with incense, garlands, burnt incense, powdered incense, flower canopies, banners, flags, and other such offering articles, in order to attain the fragrance of precepts and mastery.
With conch shells, flutes, lutes, waist drums, large drums, thunder drums, hand claps, and various other musical instruments, one should make offerings, in order to attain the divine ear.
Make various kinds of lamp wheels and offer them to the caityas,
Give canopies, leather shoes, riding animals, carriages, and so forth.
In the caityas, one should make offerings with various fragrant oils, butter lamps, garlands, and so forth, in order to attain the Buddha's eye.

Give umbrellas, leather shoes, elephants, horses, carriages, and vehicles, in order to attain the unsurpassed spiritual powers of a bodhisattva and not find them difficult.ğŸ”½One should be devoted to delighting in the Dharma, delighting in knowing and believing in the Buddha,
Delighting in serving the Saá¹…gha, and also delighting in hearing the true Dharma.
Among them, bodhisattvas should always delight in the Dharma like this, and not delight in the five desires and blessings.
One should know that the benefits obtained from believing in the Buddha are not just in believing and delighting in seeing the physical body.
One should always delight in serving the Saá¹…gha with various offerings, and not just delight in visiting and inquiring.
Always delight in hearing the Dharma without being content, and not just delight in temporarily hearing their words.
Not born in the past, not abiding in the present,
Not reaching the future - thus observe all dharmas.
Because of the power of the combination of causes and conditions and because of having nowhere to come from, they are not born in the past;
Because of being destroyed moment by moment and because of not abiding, they do not abide in the present;
Because of being extinguished without remainder and because of having nowhere to go, they do not reach the future.
One should observe all dharmas like this.
Giving good things to sentient beings, not seeking good rewards,
I should alone endure suffering, and not selfishly enjoy happiness.
Bodhisattvas should benefit and bring happiness to sentient beings with good things, and not hope for those sentient beings to benefit and bring happiness to themselves.
And for the immeasurable suffering of sentient beings, I alone endure it for them.
I have means of happiness, which I share with sentient beings to bring them joy.
Although I have great merit and reward, my mind is neither arrogant nor joyful;
Although I am poor like a hungry ghost, I am neither downcast nor worried.
Even if dwelling in the heavens with great merit and reward, one's mind should not be joyful or arrogant.

Even if one is a hungry ghost, poor, destitute, and oppressed, it is most difficult to survive, one should not give rise to a lowly mind, nor should one worry, let alone be poor and destitute in the human realm.
If there are those who have already studied, one should greatly respect them;
For those who have not studied, one should cause them to enter study, and should not give rise to contempt.
If there are sentient beings who have already studied, one should be extremely respectful towards them.
If there are those who have not studied, one should cause them to enter study, and should not despise them.
Those who are endowed with precepts should be revered, and those who violate precepts should be caused to enter the precepts.
Those who are endowed with wisdom should be befriended, and the ignorant should be caused to abide in wisdom.
One who is perfect in precepts should be greeted, with palms joined in respect, and so forth, and should be revered. One should also explain to them the merit of upholding precepts.
If there are those who violate precepts, one should cause them to enter the precepts, and should also explain to them the offenses of violating precepts.
Those who are perfect in wisdom should be befriended, and one should also reveal to them the virtues of wisdom.
The ignorant should be caused to abide in wisdom, and one should also expound to them the faults of ignorance.
There are many kinds of suffering in samsara, such as birth, old age, death, and evil destinies.
Not fearing these kinds of dread, one should subdue the evil wisdom of Mara.

Bodhisattvas, while transmigrating through the many kinds of transmigration, such as birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress, and through the evil destinies such as hell, animal realm, and hungry ghost realm, should not be afraid, but should only subdue the evil mÄras and evil wisdom.ğŸ”½All the buddha lands,
The heaps of various merits,ğŸ”½In order to attain them all,
One should make vows and strive.

The immeasurable buddha lands in the ten directions, whether the buddha lands are complete or adorned, whether one hears from the buddhas and bodhisattvas or sees them oneself, they are all heaps of supreme merits, causing them all to enter and reach one's own buddha land.
One should make such vows, and according to the vows, one will immediately accomplish them. One should also practice diligently in this way.ğŸ”½Always in all dharmas,
Without grasping, one practices letting go,ğŸ”½This is for all sentient beings,
Taking up the burden and wishing to carry it.
Because of grasping, there is suffering; because of non-grasping, there is happiness.
Having had this thought, one always abandons without grasping at any dharmas.

Although one abandons without grasping, if one previously made a vow and took on the burden for the sake of attaining enlightenment, thinking Those who are not yet liberated I shall liberate, those who are not yet freed I shall free, those who are not yet in quiescence I shall bring to quiescence,
one should bear this burden for the sake of all beings.
Correctly contemplate all dharmas as devoid of self and what belongs to self,
and do not abandon great compassion and great loving-kindness.
It is said that all dharmas are inexistent, like a dream, like an illusion.
All dharmas are devoid of self, and what belongs to the self is contemplated as signless.
In this way, when contemplating these characteristics with the supreme meaning of the Dharma, one also does not abandon great compassion and great loving-kindness for beings.
In this way, one should double one's contemplation and exclaim in wonder.
Those sentient beings are covered by the darkness of ignorance, attached to self and what belongs to self, and do not realize this supreme truth and path.
When will I cause those sentient beings to realize this supreme truth and path?
This is called not abandoning great compassion and great kindness towards sentient beings.ğŸ”½Surpassing all offerings,
with offerings to the Buddha, the World-Honored One,
what is that which is done?
It is called the offering of the Dharma.

If one makes offerings to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and the Buddha, the World-Honored One, with various offering articles, such as offering flowers, incense, garlands, powdered incense, and lamps, or making offerings with parasols, banners, and flags, or making offerings with various kinds of music, or making offerings by giving various kinds of delicious food and drink,
if one wishes to surpass all those offerings and make offerings to the Buddha,
what is that which is done?
The answer is: it is called the offering of the Dharma.
What are the characteristics of that Dharma offering?ğŸ”½If one upholds the Bodhisattva Canon
And attains dhÄraá¹‡Ä«,ğŸ”½Entering the profound source and bottom of the Dharma,
This is the Dharma offering.

Among them, if it accords with the Bodhisattva Canon, it is the profound characteristics of the sÅ«tras and so forth spoken by the TathÄgata, turning away from all worldly realms, difficult to fathom, difficult to see subtly, without attachment, definitive meaning, sealed with the king of dhÄraá¹‡Ä« sÅ«tras.
The cause of non-retrogression arises from the six pÄramitÄs, skillfully subsuming what is subsumed, in accord with entering the factors that assist in realizing bodhi,
Conforming to the nature of right enlightenment, entering the great compassion and speaking of great kindness, free from the views of the mÄras, skillfully speaking of dependent origination,
Entering the absence of sentient beings, life, nourishment, and person, in accord with emptiness,
Signlessness, wishlessness, and the characteristics of non-action, sitting in the site of enlightenment and turning the wheel of Dharma,
Praised by devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, crossing over the mud of householders,
It subsumes all sages and expounds the practices of bodhisattvas, entering into the eloquence of Dharma, meaning, and joyful speech.
It rumbles with the sounds of impermanence, suffering, and no-self, frightening
the views and attachments of non-Buddhist treatises and gains. Praised by all buddhas, it remedies saá¹ƒsÄra and reveals the bliss of nirvÄá¹‡a.
Such sÅ«tras, if expounded and upheld, are observed and subsumed, which is called Dharma offering.
Moreover, Dharma offering means not regressing and following the practice of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«.
In the profound Dharma of emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, and non-action, one enters to the very bottom without wavering or doubt. This is called the Dharma offering of the supreme meaning.
One should rely on the meaning, not just love the mixed flavors,
In the path of the profound Dharma, skillfully enter without negligence.

Furthermore, the offering of Dharma means contemplating the Dharma, practicing the Dharma, in accordance with dependent origination, free from the views of grasping extremes, attaining the acceptance of non-arising and non-cessation, entering into non-self, without contradiction, dispute, or contention regarding causes and conditions, free from self and what belongs to self.
One should rely on the meaning and not chase after the various adornments of words and phrases.
One should rely on wisdom and not on consciousness.
One should rely on the definitive sÅ«tras and not be attached to the provisional worldly expressions.
One should rely on the Dharma and not grasp at the views of individuals.

One should follow the practice of the true Dharma and enter the abode of non-abiding, skillfully observing ignorance, formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress, all of which are completely extinguished.

Having contemplated dependent origination in this way, one draws out the inexhaustible [Dharma] in order to have compassion for sentient beings, not being attached to various views or acting carelessly.
If one always acts like this, it is called the unsurpassed Dharma offering.
Thus, this accumulation, for eons equal to the sands of the Ganges,
The renunciant and the householder, will attain perfect enlightenment.

As previously explained, for eons equal to the sands of the Ganges, for the renunciant and householder bodhisattvas of the bodhisattva vehicle, after a long time fulfilling their vows, they will attain perfect enlightenment.
The verses on accumulating that merit, contemplating for the sake of enlightenment,
The meaning of accumulation is not lacking, able to be like in those verses.
I now select those verses, in meaning perhaps increasing or decreasing,
Those skilled in understanding the meaning of the verses, the wise and intelligent should bear with it.
Explaining those verses on accumulating merit, the good merit I have created,
For the sake of sentient beings in cyclic existence, I will attain perfect and complete enlightenment.
The Bodhisattva-caryavatara composed by the noble Nagarjuna is completed, and my explanation is also completed.
